case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Zamindar of Bhadra Estate

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 510/1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 22, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 35 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 22, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 35 of 1959. Sen and I. N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on April 22, 1964 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 22, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by special leave raises the question whether the expression income-tax

facts.text: The respondent was the zamindar of Bhadra Estate in Balaghat District of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are as follows The respondent was the zamindar of Bhadra Estate in Balaghat District of Madhya Pradesh. His estate was known as Bahela Zamindari

facts.text: His estate was known as Bahela Zamindari consisting of 78 villages.

anchor.surface_text: His estate was known as Bahela Zamindari companysisting of 78 villages. The Act came into force on January 26, 1951. Under the Act the proprietary rights

facts.text: The Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estate, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, 1950 (M.P. Act No. 1 of 1951) came into force on January 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on January 26, 1951. Under the Act the proprietary rights of the zamindari vested in the State and he became entitled to companypensation

facts.text: Under the Act the proprietary rights of the zamindari vested in the State.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Act the proprietary rights of the zamindari vested in the State and he became entitled to companypensation in respect of the said rights in the said

facts.text: The zamindar became entitled to compensation in respect of the said rights in the said villages under s. 8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and he became entitled to companypensation in respect of the said rights in the said villages under s. 8 ,of the Act. The companypensation was to be determined in ac-

facts.text: Compensation was to be determined in accordance with the rules contained in Schedule I to the Act.

anchor.surface_text: companypensation was to be determined in ac- companydance with the rules companytained in Schedule I to the Act. Under r. 8 of Schedule I the zamindar would be entitled

facts.text: Under r. 8 of Schedule I the zamindar would be entitled to compensation at 10 times the net income.

anchor.surface_text: Under r. 8 of Schedule I the zamindar would be entitled to ,compensation at 10 times the net income. The net income would be calculated by deducting from the gross

facts.text: Net income calculated by deducting from gross income, inter alia, the average of the income-tax paid in respect of the income from big forest during 30 agricultural years preceding March 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: income. The net income would be calculated by deducting from the gross income, inter- alia, the average of the income-tax paid in respect of the income from big forest

facts.text: On November 30, 1951, the Compensation Officer determined the compensation payable to the respondent at Rs. 2,21,330-12-6.

anchor.surface_text: during 30 agricultural years preceding March 31, 1951. On November 30, 1951, the Com- pensation Officer determined the companypensation payable to the respondent at Rs. 2,21,330-12-6.

facts.text: Compensation Officer deducted not only the income-tax but also the super-tax and surcharge payable by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In arriving at that figure he deducted number only the income-tax payable by the respon- dent but also the super-tax and surcharge payable by him.

facts.text: Average of the income-tax paid during the 30 years was Rs. 3,760-2-9.

anchor.surface_text: The average of the income-tax paid by him during the mateI 30 years was only Rs. 3,760-2-9, but if the average of -,the super-tax and surcharge was included,

facts.text: Average including super-tax and surcharge was Rs. 7,070-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: but if the average of -,the super-tax and surcharge was included, the average came to Rs. 7,070-8-0. The result was that the net yearly income of the estate was

facts.text: Net yearly income of the estate was reduced by Rs. 3,310-5-3.

anchor.surface_text: the average came to Rs. 7,070-8-0. The result was that the net yearly income of the estate was reduced by Rs. 3,310-5-3 and companypensation was paid to him

facts.text: The respondent moved the Settlement Commissioner under s. 15 of the Act for enhancement of the compensation.

anchor.surface_text: and companypensation was paid to him on the basis of the amount so reduced. The- respondent moved the Settlement Commissioner under s. 15 of the Act for enhancement

facts.text: The Commissioner confirmed the order of the Compensation Officer.

anchor.surface_text: of the companypensation, but the Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Compensation Officer. Thereafter, the respondent filed an application in the High

facts.text: The respondent filed an application in the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Compensation Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent filed an application in the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Compensation Officer.

facts.text: The High Court held that super-tax should not be taken into account while calculating the compensation payable to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held, on a companystruction of the relevant provisions. of the Act, that super-tax should number be taken into account while calculating the companypensation

facts.text: The State of Madhya Pradesh filed the present appeal against the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: payable to the respondent. The State of Madhya Pradesh has filed the present appeal against the order of the High Court.

issues.text: whether the expression income-tax in cl. c of sub-r. 2 of r. 2 of Schedule I to the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estate, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, 1950 M.P. Act No. 1 of 1951, hereinafter called the Act, includes super-tax

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether the expression income-tax in cl. c of sub-r. 2 of r. 2 of Schedule I to the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estate, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, 1950 M.P. Act No. 1 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Act, includes super-tax.

arguments.claim: The object of r. 2(2)(c) is to provide a method for ascertaining net income of estate; no justifiable distinction between income-tax and super-tax as both deducted from gross income to net income

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen, learned counsel for the State, contends that the object of r. 2 2  c  is to provide a method for ascertaining the net income of an estate, that in that context there cannot be any justifiable distinction between income-tax and super-tax, for both of them have, inter alia,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge that under the Income-tax Act two separate duties, namely, in- companye-tax and super-tax, are imposed, the Legislature has used t

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislative intention manifest from express language excluding super-tax; super-tax not paid in respect of big forest income but total income

arguments.claim: Legislature used 'income-tax' in comprehensive sense including super-tax; under Income-tax Act super-tax is additional duty of income-tax and part of it

anchor.surface_text: and that the Legislature used the word income-tax in its comprehensive sense so as to take in super-tax. He adds that under the Income-tax Act super-tax is only an additional duty of income-tax and, therefore, a part of it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Knowledge of two separate duties under IT Act; used only 'income-tax'; expressio unius excludes super-tax

arguments.claim: In construing provision of expropriatory Act, construe strictly; super-tax cannot be included in 'income-tax'; super-tax different in origin, description, scope, incidents, collection from income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopala Sastri, learned counsel for the respondent- assessee, argues that in construing a provision of an ex- proprietary Act, the Court will have to construe such a pro- vision strictly and if so construed, super-tax cannot be in- cluded

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sation Officer. The High Court held, on a companystruction of the relevant provisions. of the Act, that super-tax should number be taken into account

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions of expropriatory Acts construed strictly; express language and context support exclusion

arguments.claim: Super-tax distinct from income-tax: separate history, introduced 1917, incorporated 1922 but separate chapter Ch.IX ss.55-58; different charging, assessment

anchor.surface_text: Till the 1922 Act super-tax was separately levied. It was first introduced by the Super-tax Act of 1917 and then it was replaced by the 1920 Act. Only in 1922, for the first time, it was incorporated in the

arguments.claim: Essential differences between income-tax and super-tax: super-tax on total income without heads; cannot attribute super-tax to specific source like big forest income

anchor.surface_text: though both the taxes are assessed on the total income ofa person, the total income for the purpose of income-tax is computed on the basis of income classified and chargeable under the different heads mentioned in s. 6 of the Act, whereas super- tax is not concerned with the different heads,

arguments.claim: Legislative intention: used 'income-tax' knowing two separate duties; omission of super-tax indicates exclusion (expressio unius)

anchor.surface_text: With the knowledge that under the Income-tax Act two separate duties, namely, in- come-tax and super-tax, are imposed, the Legislature has used the expression income-tax. If the intention was to refer to both the taxes,

arguments.claim: 'Income-tax paid in respect of income from big forest' excludes super-tax as super-tax paid on total income, not specific income; no machinery to allocate

anchor.surface_text: The qualification that income-tax paid should have been in respect of the income received from the big forest neces- sarily excludes super-tax, for under the Income-tax Act no super-tax is payable in respect of the income received from big forest, but only in respect of the total income.

arguments.claim: Respondent's argument that 30 years precede super-tax introduction is not sound as super-tax existed from 1917

anchor.surface_text: The argument of Mr. Rajagopala Sastri, learned counsel for the respondent, that the 30 years mentioned in the rule takes us back to a period when there was no super-tax appears to be not sound, for, as we have stated earlier, supertax was payable

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he taxable level. In that event super-tax number payable in respect of the income from big forest will have to be deducted. That apart, the rules made

arguments.claim: Proper approach for expropriatory statute: why Legislature did not mention super-tax if intended to include

anchor.surface_text: The argument that if the Legislature intended not to exclude super-tax from the gross-income, it would have expressly stated so in the rule is an attempt to put the shoe on the wrong foot. The proper approach, particularly in the case of an exproprietary statute,

arguments.claim: Deductions only those with direct relation to estate income; including super-tax leads to speculation

anchor.surface_text: The reason for the rule... appears to be that as it is concerned with the calculation of the net-income from the estate after making certain deductions, only those deductions, which have a direct relation to that income are allowed.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Bates v Bates: super-tax not deductible where income-tax specified as not charge on particular income

anchor.surface_text: In Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates, a testator gave... after deduction of the income tax... held... not entitled to payment of any sum in respect of super-tax... No super-tax is really payable in respect of this sum.

arguments.claim: On construction of relevant provisions of Act, super-tax should not be taken into account in calculating compensation

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees on interpretation excluding super-tax

holdings.text: the expression 'income-tax' in cl. c of sub-r. 2 of r. 2 of Schedule I to the Act does not include super-tax

anchor.surface_text: raises the question whether the expression income-tax in cl. c of sub-r. 2 of r. 2 of Schedule I to the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estate, Mahals, Alienated Lands Act, 1950 M.P. Act No. 1 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Act, includes super-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature knowingly used 'income-tax' excluding super-tax (expressio unius); super-tax levied on total income not specific big forest income; distinct history, charging sections, no allocation mechanism; strict construction for expropriatory statute; precedents like Bates analogous

holdings.text: super-tax is a distinct tax from income-tax with separate charging provision, assessment basis, and incidents

anchor.surface_text: Only in 1922, for the first time, it was incorporated in the Income-tax Act. Though both the taxes are dealt with by the same Act, their distinctive features are maintained. As regards income-tax, in the words of a learned author, s. 3 charges the total income, s. 4 define its range, s. 6 qualifies it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical evolution from separate Super-tax Acts to incorporation in IT Act 1922 but retained in separate Ch. IX ss.55-58; different computation (heads vs total income), payment modes; no shared machinery

holdings.text: No super-tax is payable 'in respect of the income received from big forest' but only in respect of total income

anchor.surface_text: The qualification that income-tax paid should have been in respect of the income received from the big forest neces- sarily excludes super-tax, for under the Income-tax Act no super-tax is payable in respect of the income received from big forest, but only in respect of the total income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule specifies tax 'paid in respect of' specific income source; super-tax charged on total income without head-wise attribution; no statutory machinery for apportionment

holdings.text: Provisions of an expropriatory statute must be construed strictly

anchor.surface_text: in construing a provision of an ex- proprietary Act, the Court will have to construe such a pro- vision strictly and if so construed, super-tax cannot be in- cluded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper approach asks why Legislature omitted 'super-tax' if intended; favors exclusion on express language in property-vesting context

holdings.text: The reasoning in Bates case applies by analogy to exclude super-tax where 'income-tax' specified for particular income

anchor.surface_text: In Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates, a testator gave... after deduction of the income tax... held... not entitled to payment of any sum in respect of super-tax... No super-tax is really payable in respect of this sum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parity: income-tax deductible for specific sum/source, super-tax on total not attributable; helpful though will-specific

precedents.case_name: Brooks v Commissioner of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: super-tax is another and a new tax, though an additional duty of income-tax
precedents.cited_holding: for super-tax tax is another and a new tax numbere the less, though it is an additional duty of Income Tax

precedents.citation: Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates 2 1925 Ch. D. 157, 159-160, 161

anchor.surface_text: In Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates 2 , a testator gave to his wife by his will such a sum in every year as after deduction of the income tax for the time being payable in respect thereof will leave a clear sum of pound 2000. It was held that the wife was entitled to the pound 2000 free of income-tax only and was number entitled to payment of any sum in respect of super-tax. There the trustees were directed to pay the annuity after deducting the income tax in respect of that annuity. Rejecting the argument advanced on behalf of the wife that the said annuity should be free from super-tax also, Russell. J., observed Now super-tax was number a charge in respect of any particular annuity or sum, but was a charge in respect of the recipients whole income and was number a matter with which the trustees would be charged or companycerned at all, and, in his opinion, what the testator had done was to give the widow the yearly sum of pound 2500 clear of all deductions, for which the trustees were accountable, but that did number include super-tax, which she must pay herself.  1  19l4  7-T. C. 2 3 6, 2 5 S. 2 1925 Ch. D. 157, 159-160, 161, The learned Judge proceeded to state No super-tax is really payable in respect of this sum.

precedents.cited_proposition: super-tax is not a charge in respect of any particular income or annuity but in respect of the recipient's whole income
precedents.cited_holding: the wife was entitled to the pound 2000 free of income-tax only and was number entitled to payment of any sum in respect of super-tax [...] No super-tax is really payable in respect of this sum

precedents.citation: Reckitt, In re Reckitt v. Reckitt 1

anchor.surface_text: In Reckitt, In re Reckitt v. Reckitt 1 , a fund was bequeathed to trustees upon trust for investment and to pay out of the income of the investments the annual sum of pound 5000 free of income-tax during the life of the annuitant. The Court of Appeal held that the annuitant was entitled to have the sum paid to her without deduction on account of super-tax and that the trustees must pay the super-tax payable in respect of that sum out of the income of the fund. The conclusion turned upon the provisions of the will.

precedents.cited_proposition: in certain wills, annuitant entitled to income free of income-tax, with trustees bearing super-tax
precedents.cited_holding: the annuitant was entitled to have the sum paid to her without deduction on account of super-tax and that the trustees must pay the super-tax payable in respect of that sum out of the income of the fund

precedents.citation: Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates 2

anchor.surface_text: Lord Hanworth, M.R., distinguished the decision in Bates, In re Selmes v. Bates 2  on the ground that Russell, J., founded his judgment upon the reference to deductions and also upon the direction to, the trustees that specified sum should be paid after deduction of income-tax in respect thereof and proceeded to observe that in the case before them numberreference was made to, the system, or the power of the trustees to make deductions-.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinguished on grounds relating to will provisions about deductions by trustees

anchor.surface_text: As super-tax is number a charge in respect of the income from big forest, on the parity of reasoning it shall be held that the word income-tax used in cl.  c  of r. 2 2  of Schedule I to the Act excludes super-tax.

outcome.relief_summary: Expression 'income-tax' in r. 2(2)(c) of Schedule I excludes super-tax; net income calculation excludes super-tax; High Court order upheld, State appeal dismissed
